title: Edit an offering
content:
You can edit multiple records simultaneously by selecting them in the grid and updating them in the Preview pane on the right. For more information, see Mass update.

  1. From the main menu, select Plan > Service Catalog > Offerings.

  2. Select the offering you want to update.

    To filter the record list, click the Add filter  button. For more information, see Filters.

  3. Click the record identifier in the ID column to display the selected record.

  4. The General tab of the offering record is active by default. Click the tab you want to edit or view.

    Tab Description
    General General details for the offering. For more information, see the section General tab
    User options User options are specific user defined attributes for an offering. For more information, see the "User options tab" section of this topic.
    Price Prices for the offering. For more information, see the section Price tab.
    Rules

    Defined business rules for a request offering.

    For each of the process events, you can add rules to run before or after the general record business rules. For more information, see Offering business rules.
    Task Plan Task plan and approval plan for processing the request offering. For more information, see the "Task plan tab" section of this topic.
    Default values Set default values for the details of the offering. For more information, see the "Default values tab" section of this topic.
    Discussions Displays any relevant conversations about the selected record. For more information, see Discussions.
    History Displays changes to the selected record. For more information, see History.
  5. Save your changes.
  • The Number of requests field in offering is calculated by a scheduler.
  • Number of requests counts all the requests opened for an active offering over the past month. For example, if today is November 15, then the past month would span from October 15 to November 15.
  • When there are more than 250 active offerings in the system, only the first 250 active offerings ordered by Number of requests (in ascending order) will be countered.


General tab

This tab includes the following sections:

Offering details

Field Description
Display label

The name of the offering. This is also the display title.
Description A description of the offering.
Status
  • Active. The offering is available in the Service Portal and in the Service Request Management module, depending on the entitled audience. The offering is also available to an Agent dealing with a Live Support call.
  • Inactive. The offering isn't available in the Service Portal, nor in the Service Request Management module.
  • Internal. The offering isn't available to a user in the Service Portal, but it's available in the Service Request Management module. The offering is also available to an Agent dealing with a Live Support call.
  • Unpublished. This status indicates that the offering isn't active in the catalog but is still available for cloud subscription operations. For example, when you migrate a subscription from Cloud Service Automation (CSA) to Cloud Management, although the associated offering in CSA isn't available, an "Unpublished" offering should still be available in Cloud Management to support a cloud subscription lifecycle. When the offering is in the "Unpublished" status, the offering isn't available in Service Portal, nor in the Service Request Management module. However, end users can still modify or cancel the associated subscriptions in Service Portal.
Offering type
  • Support Offering. Offering related to support requests.
  • Service Offering. Offering related to service requests. On creation, the aggregated offering has this default value.
  • HR Support Offering. Offering related to human resources requests.
  • Case Offering: Offering related to case requests.

 On selection of Offering bundle, the value must be Service Offering or HR Support Offering.
Offered asset model The model of the asset needed for the offering. When a request consumes the offering, the request searches the stockrooms for an asset matching the asset model.
Service definition The service to which the offering belongs.
Offering bundle

Select this check box to indicate that the offering is an offering bundle, that's, a bundle of offerings.

An offering bundle can only be a Service Offering or HR Support Offering.
Default offering

Select this check box to define the offering as a default offering. Service Portal uses default offerings in the Request Support screen when the user doesn't select any suitable offering from the system suggested offerings.

You can create multiple default offerings, for example, based on a user’s entitlement rules.

Use case example: In multinational organizations, local IT can set default offerings for all users with the same location. This way the offering is ready and the local IT will route it to the right help desk in the right location.
Promote

The value in this field controls the order in which offerings (and articles, using a similar field) are displayed on the catalog and category pages of the Service Portal.

The priority order of the display is:

  • Recommended
  • Normal
  • Deprecated

The IT department can promote offerings using this feature. For example, they may want to promote a new Skype for Business headset so that more users start using Skype for Business. It can also help them phase out old offerings, but still keep the offerings at hand in case they're needed again.
Hide attachment in Service Portal Select this check box to disable the Attachments section in the Service Portal.
Provider The provider of the aggregated offering. It's a read-only field and available only in aggregated offerings.
Service Design The name and version of the service design for the aggregated offering. It's a read-only field and available only in aggregated offerings.
Action type

If appropriate, select the action to match the offering.

For example, for an offering that creates a subscription, select Create subscription. For an offering that cancels a subscription, select Cancel. For an offering that updates a record, select Update.

The default value for this field is Create, update, cancel, and pause while creating an aggregated offering.

If you set Action type as Update, Cancel or Pause rather than Create subscription, and select the Required asset information as Subscription in an offering, then create a request based on this offering, the subscription won't be changed even if the request is fulfilled.
Required asset information

Defines the asset - device, infrastructure, actual service, enterprise asset, or subscription - required to classify a request under this offering. This is sometimes connected to Action type.

For example, assume there is an offering named Increase VM memory. The Action type for the offering is Update. The Required asset information would be Device because, to fulfill the request, the help desk first needs to know which VM should have its memory increased. Fulfilling the request would update the VM record.

As another example, assume there is an offering Check my PC age. Again the help desk needs to know which PC the request is for. So, the Required asset information would be Device. But in this case, Action type will be empty, because the offering isn't intended to create, update, cancel, or pause the device.

Available when: Action type isn't Create subscription.
Require company information This field is available when CSM is enabled and the offering type is Service, Support, or Case. Selecting this checkbox makes the Requested by company and Requested for company information mandatory when creating a service, support, or case request.
Required entitlement information
This field is available only when CSM is enabled and the offering type is Service, Support, or Case. It has two options:
  • Product: Selecting this option makes the Product instance information mandatory when creating a service, support, or case request.
  • Product and Entitlement: Selecting this option makes both Product instance and Entitlement information mandatory when creating a service, support, or case request.
If no option is selected, Product Instance and Entitlement information are not required when creating a service, support, or case request.
Entitlement filter This field is available when CSM is enabled and the offering type is Service, Support, or Case. It controls the offering’s visibility based on product entitlements. To understand how it affects visibility, see the Audience section on this page.
Image A representative icon for the offering.

Agreements

Select an SLA and an OLA/UC in the Agreements session. Only active agreements appear in the drop-down lists. Selected agreements decide the Service Level Target for the request based on this offering. For more information, see Service Level Management.

Submission via email

Select Allow request creation from email check box to enable the automatic creation of a request. On the selection of Allow request creation from email, you can see the field Questionnaire. Enter questions related to the offering. The system will use the responses to the question for processing the service request.

A user will be able to submit a request by clicking a link in a specially prepared email sent by the Service Portal.

If this check box isn't selected, clicking the link in the email will direct you to the Service Portal to open a request.

Audience

The Audience section defines which users can view and request the offering in the service portal. Visibility is generally controlled through entitlement rules. However, if Customer Service Management (CSM) is enabled, then for Service, Support, and Case offerings, you can also use product entitlements, along with entitlement rules, to control access.

Entitlement rules

Entitlement rules restrict access based on location, user group, role, or company. These rules can be created by administrators under Administration > Master Data > People > Entitlement Rules. For more information, see How to manage entitlement rules. After creating a rule, you must add it to the offering’s Audience section to enforce it.

Add entitlement rule in the Audience section

  1. Click Add  , then select the rule from the list or type a few characters to search for the rule.
    OR
    Click the list icon   (   ) to display the available entitlement rules. Select the checkboxes for the rules you want to add, then click OK.
    The selected rules appear in yellow. 
  2. Click Save on the toolbar.

Remove entitlement rule in the Audience section

  1. Select   the rule and click Remove. The selected rules appear in strikethrough text. 
  2. Click Save on the toolbar.

Product entitlements

A product entitlement record defines which users from a customer company, or its delegated companies, can view requests, create or update requests, and view articles for the product instances purchased by the customer. For more information, see the Manage entitlements page.

Restricting visibility based on product entitlements

When CSM is enabled, the Entitlement filter is visible in the Offering details section. It provides a single option: Entitled products. Selecting this option displays the Related product model section below the Related asset model section. You must add the relevant product models in this section. As a result, in the service portal, the users can view and request the offering only if they:

  • Have entitlements to create or update requests for product instances of the specified product models.
  • Satisfy the added entitlement rules, if any.
If you set the Entitlement filter to Entitled products, you must add the relevant product models in the Related product model section. If no product models are added, the offering will not be visible to any users, even those who satisfy the entitlement rules.
If you do not want to use product entitlements to restrict visibility, leave the Entitlement filter unset. In this case, the offering will be visible only to users who meet the entitlement rules.

Examples of controlling offering's visibility

The following examples show how entitlement rules and product entitlements affect offering access.

  • Using entitlement rules only: An organization wants an offering "Submit Travel Request" to be visible only to employees in the India office who belong to the Finance group. Create an entitlement rule specifying Location as India and Group as Finance, add the rule to the offering’s Audience section. Only users in the India Finance group can request the offering.
     
  • Using product entitlements only – CSM Use Case: A company provides a "Troubleshooting " offering for the XYZ software product. Only customers who have purchased XYZ should be able to request it. Set the offering's Audience section Entitlement filter to Entitled products and the XYZ product model in the Related product model section. Only users from customer company with entitlements granting permission to raise requests for product instances of the ABC product can request the offering.
     
  • Using both entitlement rules and product entitlements – CSM Use Case: A company wants a "Report Issue" offering for the XYZ product to be visible only to customers who have purchased the product and are located in the USA.  Create an entitlement rule specifying Location as USA, and add the rule to the offering’s Audience section. Set the Entitlement filter to Entitled products and add the XYZ product model. Only users who meet both conditions can request the offering.

Public audience

Use this option to set whether and how you can share the requests created under the offering. You can do the following for a shared request.

  • Find it (by searching)
  • View it
  • Comment on it
  • Follow it
  • Not follow it
  • Receive updates on it

In addition, if you follow the request, the system will promote your comment as a solution.

Configure the option as below.

Field Description
Allow public

Use this option to decide whether you want to share the request under the offering:

  • Never - never shared.
  • Optional - Determines sharing for each request when the Service Portal user receives a confirmation message that the request has been successfully submitted.
  • Always - always shared according to the Public scope setting.
Public scope

This setting determines the extent of sharing:

If Allow public is set to Never:

  • Private - the Requested by user and Requested for user can see the request in the Service Portal.
  • Confidential - Hides the request from the Requested for user in the Service Portal, and only the Request by user can see the request.

If Allow public is set to Optional or Always:

  • Location - at the same location hierarchy as that of the person in the Requested for field of the request.

    Configure the location hierarchy in the Service Portal feature settings. It's one of the following:

    • Country

    • City

    • Office

    • Building

    • Floor

    For example, suppose the person in the Requested for field of the request is in this location: North America > United States > San Diego > San Diego Office.

    You can set Public scope to Location and Location hierarchy to City for sharing it with those in North America > United States > San Diego.

    You can set the Public scope to Location and Location hierarchy to Country for sharing it with those in North America > United States.

  • Organization - shared with people who are in the same organization as that of the person in the Requested for field of the request.

  • Location & organization - shared with people who have the same location (as earlier) or are in the same organization, as that of the person in the Requested for field of the request.

Related asset model

You can select asset model records to relate to the offering.

To add a linked record:

  1. Click Add or the grid icon .
  2. Select the record(s). The added items appear in yellow.
  3. Click Save.

To remove a linked record:

  1. Select the record(s).
  2. Click Remove. The selected items appear in strikethrough text.
  3. Click Save.

Related product model

This section is visible after you select the Entitled products option in Entitlement filter within the Offering details section. In this section, you must add the relevant product model records to control visibility.
 

If no product models are added, the offering will not be visible to any users, including those who meet entitlement rules. 
Only product models of type Product can be added. Product models of type Bundle or Category are not supported.
To add a related product model record:
  1. Click Add or the grid icon .
  2. Select the record(s). The added items appear in yellow.
  3. Click Save.
To remove a related product model record:
  1. Select the record(s).
  2. Click Remove. The selected items appear in strikethrough text.
  3. Click Save.

Financial information

Specify the financial information of the offering.

Field Description
Cost center

Indicates which business unit to charge.
Cost type The type of the cost.

User options tab

You can define user options in one of the following ways: 

  • Define user options in the User options tab in the offering record
  • Populate the user options using an existing fulfillment plan

Define user options in the User options tab in the offering record

You can define user options as individual fields. You can also classify the fields into different groups and sections if you need to manage multiple user options with different types. Pay attention to the following:

You can define up to 3 levels of depth for sections and groups if required. 
Deleting a section or a group will delete all subgroups, subsections, and fields under the section or group. You can't delete a section, a group, or a field for aggregated service designs.
When you filter by user options in grid view, if you select a section or a group, no result can be found. This is a limitation.

Add a section

  1. Click New section to add a section.

  2. (Optional) Select a group where you want the section to appear. Not selecting any group will display the section as an individual section.

  3. The right pane will show the properties for each section.
    Property Description
    Display name

    The display name of the section in the Service Management user interface.

    You can either use plain text or you can add HTML anchor tags in the Display name.

    For example, you can specify a hyperlink in the Display name: <a href="www.MyURL.com">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in the current tab. 

    Or, <a href="www.MyURL.com" target="_blank">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in a new tab.

    Besides the HTML anchor tags, other types of HTML tags are also supported. See the list of allowed HTML tags in Service Management.
    Width

    The width of the element in the Agent user interface. The Service Portal will display all fields as a fixed size, one field per line, regardless of the selected field size.

    The available sizes are:

    Medium. A field with a size of medium displays in half the width of the form.

    Large. A field with a size of large displays in the whole width of the form.
    Required Users must give this property a value when editing it from the user interface. This setting does not affect backend API calls.
    Help text

    Give help text to give some details or hints about this user option.

    The help text is displayed as a tooltip if its length exceeds 1 line. 

    • If you click on the help text, the tooltip remains visible until you press Esc or click a second time anywhere else on the screen.
    • If you don't click on the help text, the tooltip will disappear after you move the cursor away.

    You can either use plain text as a description or you can add HTML anchor tags in the Help text.

    For example, you can specify a hyperlink in the Help text: <a href="www.MyURL.com">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in the current tab.

    Or, <a href="www.MyURL.com" target="_blank">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in a new tab.

    Besides the HTML anchor tags, other types of HTML tags are also supported. See List of allowed HTML tags in Service Management.

    For an aggregated offering from a cloud service, you can edit the help text aggregated from the DND service design.

    The maximum length of the Help text is determined by an application setting called Maximum input length. The default value is 200 characters.

  4. Click the Move Up and Move down buttons on the toolbar to decide the order for the whole section, including all subgroups, subsections, and fields under this section.

Add a group

  1. Click New group to add a section.

  2. Select a section where you want the group to appear. 

  3. The right pane shows the properties of each group.
    Property Description
    Display name

    The display name of the group in the Service Management user interface.

    You can either use plain text or you can add HTML anchor tags in the Display name.

    For example, you can specify a hyperlink in the Display name: <a href="www.MyURL.com">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in the current tab. 

    Or, <a href="www.MyURL.com" target="_blank">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in a new tab.

    Besides the HTML anchor tags, other types of HTML tags are also supported. See List of allowed HTML tags in Service Management.
    Width

    The width of the element in the Agent user interface. The Service Portal will display all fields as a fixed size, one field per line, regardless of the selected field size.

    The available sizes are:

    Medium. A field with a size of medium displays in half the width of the form.

    Large. A field with a size of large displays in the whole width of the form.
    Help text

    Give help text to give some details or hints about this user option.

    The help text is displayed as a tooltip if its length exceeds 1 line. 
    - If you click on the help text, the tooltip remains visible until you press Esc or click a second time anywhere else on the screen.
    -     If you don't click on the help text, the tooltip will disappear after you move the cursor away.

    You can either use plain text as a description or you can add HTML anchor tags in the Help text.

    For example, you can specify a hyperlink in the Help text: <a href="www.MyURL.com">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in the current tab.

    Or, <a href="www.MyURL.com" target="_blank">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in a new tab.

    Besides the HTML anchor tags, other types of HTML tags are also supported. See the list of allowed HTML tags in Service Management.

    For an aggregated offering from a cloud service, you can edit the help text aggregated from DND service design.

    The maximum length of the Help text is determined by an application setting called Maximum input length. The default value is 200 characters.

  4. Click the Move Up and Move down buttons on the toolbar to decide the order for the whole section, including all subgroups, subsections, and fields under this section.
    Note: Move up and Move down buttons are inactive for the sections, groups, and fields aggregated from Service Design.

Add a field

  1. Click New field to add a field.

  2. (Optional) Select a group where you want the field to appear. Not selecting any group will display the section as an individual section.

  3. The right pane shows the properties for each field

    Property Description
    Name

    The name of the user option. The name:

    • Must start with an uppercase letter.
    • May contain alphanumeric characters only (A-Z, a-z, 0–9).
    • May not contain spaces.
    • Must end with _c. You don't need to enter it manually as the system adds it automatically.
    Display name

    The display name of the field in the Service Management user interface.

    You can either use plain text or you can add HTML anchor tags in the Display name.

    For example, you can specify a hyperlink in the Display name: <a href="www.MyURL.com">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in the current tab. 

    Or, <a href="www.MyURL.com" target="_blank">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in a new tab.

    Besides the HTML anchor tags, other types of HTML tags are also supported. See the list of allowed HTML tags in Service Management.
    Field type

    The field type:

    • String. A textual value.

    • Boolean. A true or false value.

    • Integer. A numeric value without a decimal point. 
    • Double. A numeric value with a decimal point.

    • List. A list of values. You are allowed to select one value from the list. Select a predefined list, or click  Add to define a new list. Edit the list's items if desired.

      Creating and saving a new list will display the List order field. Select Alphabetical to sort the list alphabetically, or Ordinal to sort the list by the user-defined order. For more information, see Create or edit a list in the User Options tab.

      For editable lists, you can edit the list items here. For more information, see Lists.

    • Multi-Select List. A list of values, which is similar to the List above. The only difference is that you are allowed to select multiple values from the list.

    • Date. A date value.

    • Rich text. A value in rich text format.

    • DateTime. A value with date and time.
    • Entity Link: A value that's an entity link. When selected, displays the Entity type field, allowing you to select an entity type from the list. For more information, see Use entity links in user options.

    • Encrypted String. A texture value that needs encryption. It's normally used for confidential data such as passwords. Use this type when you want to encrypt the value of the user option in the Service Management database.

      Notes:

      • The maximum length of String, Integer, and Rich text fields are the same as the maximum length of SMALL_TEXT, INTEGER, and RICH_TEXT logical types defined in Logical type details.
      • For the system to encrypt the user option in Encrypted String type, the tenant admin must set the passcode to initialize the key chain for encryption in Application Settings.

      • If you define a default value for the user option in the Encrypted String type, the default value in the template record (such as an offering or a change model) isn't encrypted; only the data entered by the end users needs encryption.

      • As Encrypted String uses a tenant key chain for encryption and the tenant key chain is different from encryption domains, you can not decrypt the encrypted data in the Encrypted String fields. Currently, the system only decrypts the value of this type when Service Management communicates with DND for cloud service deployment.
    Width

    The width of the element in the Agent user interface. The Service Portal will display all fields as a fixed size, one field per line, regardless of the selected field size.

    The available sizes are:

    Medium. A field with a size of medium displays in half the width of the form.

    Large. A field with a size of large displays in the whole width of the form.
    Required Users must give this property a value when editing it from the user interface. This setting does not affect backend API calls.
    Visibility

    Defines where the user option is visible:

    • Agent. The user option is visible in Service Management, for internal use only. For example, the calculation of this value for the user option might depend on the values of other details that the Service Portal user entered when opening a request.

    • User. The user option is visible both in Service Portal and internally in Service Management.

    Note: Enabling custom forms in the Service Portal Feature settings stops this property from being effective. You need to add Rendering Rules to control the visibility when using custom forms.
    Help text

    Give help text to give some details or hints about this user option.

    The help text is displayed as a tooltip if its length exceeds 1 line. 

    • If you click on the help text, the tooltip remains visible until you press Esc or click a second time anywhere else on the screen.
    • If you don't click on the help text, the tooltip will disappear after you move the cursor away.

    You can either use plain text as a description or you can add HTML anchor tags in the Help text.

    For example, you can specify a hyperlink in the Help text: <a href="www.MyURL.com">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in the current tab.

    Or, <a href="www.MyURL.com" target="_blank">MyURL</a>. In this example, the hyperlink will open in a new tab.

    Besides the HTML anchor tags, other types of HTML tags are also supported. See list of allowed HTML tags in Service Management.

    For an aggregated offering from a cloud service, you can edit the help text aggregated from DND service design.

    The maximum length of the Help text is determined by an application setting called Maximum input length. The default value is 200 characters. 

  4. Repeat for each new field.

  5. Click the Move Up and Move down buttons on the toolbar to decide the order for the whole section.

Populate user options using an existing fulfillment plan


This option isn't relevant for offering bundles.

In this case, select a plan from the Fulfillment Plan list. The user options from the fulfillment plan populate the user options of the task plan.

For a support offering, you can select a fulfillment plan of type Support Request. For a service offering, you can select a fulfillment plan of type Service Request or Cloud Service Request. For a case offering, you can select a fulfillment plan of type Case Request.

The fulfillment plan for the Cloud Service Request type doesn't contain user options.

To edit any of these user options, click Edit fulfillment plan, and edit the user options in the fulfillment plan itself. Keep in mind that when you update a fulfillment plan it affects all offerings that consume this fulfillment plan. For more information about fulfillment plans, see How to create or edit a fulfillment plan. 

To clear the fulfillment plan selection, click the button in the Fulfillment Plan field, as shown in the figure below.  

User options and offering bundles

For offering bundles, you must map the user options to the user options of the bundled offerings:

  1. Select a bundled offering, and click the Set user option mappings button.
  2. Enter hard coded values or Expression Language phrases for the user option mappings.
  3. Repeat for each bundled offering, for each user option you want to map.

Development and production tenants

If you have development and production tenants, make user option changes in both tenants to keep the tenants synchronized. The Dev2Prod synchronization doesn't synchronize user options. For more information, contact your administrator.

For more information, see the section How to edit an offering.

For an example of user options for pricing of offerings, see User options pricing example.

User options for aggregated offerings

For an offering aggregated from a cloud service, the user options mapping is from the service design. The catalog admin can update but can't delete the user options mapped from a service design.

The option model mapping between the service design and the offering is described in the following table.

Service design Aggregated offering
Option Set Option Section
Option Option Group
Property User Option

The table below describes some important property field mappings between a service design and an aggregated offering.

Field name (service design) Field value (service design) Field name (aggregated offering) Field value (aggregated offering)
Modifiable during service modification true or false You can update it true or false
Editable true Visibility User
false Visibility Agent
Required true or false Required true or false

The default values in the service design are also aggregated.

In addition, if a service design contains list items or input validation based on scripts, these scripts will also take effect in the aggregated offering.

On the creation of an aggregated offering, the maximum length of a user option in the String type is identical to the maximum length of LARGE_TEXT logical type, which is much longer than the one in a standard offering (maximum length of SMALL_TEXT logical type). If you change the user option type to something else and then change it back to String, the maximum length of the user option becomes the same as the standard offering.

Price tab

This tab splits into a Default tab and an Advanced tab. 

With the Catalog Administrator role, you can:

  • In the Default tab, specify whether price information is visible to Service Portal users, and define the basic upfront and recurring price, together with the additional price per user options.
  • In the Advanced tab, define the price based on location.

Default tab

This tab displays the following:

  • Visible to Service Portal

    Select this option if you want the price to display in the Service Portal.

    If selected, this only affects the display of price information. Any request created using the offering continues to use price values as configured.

  • Basic pricing

    Field Description
    Currency The currency used for the price.
    Price The basic, minimum, upfront price of the offering.
    Recurring price

    The extra amount charged for the offering. For the recurring period specified, there will be an extra charge according to the value configured for the recurring price. 

    For example, if the recurring price is $5 and the recurring period is monthly, every month there is an extra $5 charge for the offering.
    Recurring period

    If applicable, this is the recurring price chargeable for the offering.

  • Pricing per user options

    If applicable, the system will display any user options added to the basic pricing. Valid user options for pricing are either Boolean or list type.

    For example, you might configure an offering for a server so that the price increase depends on the CPU and the memory size. For an example of user options for pricing of offerings, see User options pricing example.
    Note: You can't define additional price on the option groups added for an offering (not the aggregated offering).

Advanced tab

This tab displays location based pricing information for the offering.

  1. Click Add Location to add a location.
  2. Complete the pricing details for the location.
  3. Click Save.

You may add multiple locations to define pricing for different locations. For an example, see Advanced pricing example.

Rules tab

For each of the process events, you can add rules to run before or after the general record business rules. For more information, see Offering business rules.

Task plan tab

A task/approval plan is a set of tasks/approvals in a record's workflow that should be completed before moving the record from one phase to the next. A task plan may include automated tasks, manual tasks, and decisions to decide which path of the task flow to follow. An approval plan includes approval tasks, and may contain decisions to decide which path of the approval plan to follow.

 for offering bundles only: When you add an offering to an offering bundle, Service Management creates an automated task in the task plan. When the offering reaches the Fulfill phase, each automated task in the task plan triggers the creation of a child request for its respective bundled offering. The automated task is also responsible for monitoring the progress of the offering. For more information, see How to create a request record.

You can customize the task plan as with a task plan for any offering.

Limitation: Each time you add an offering to the offering bundle or remove a bundled offering from the offering bundle, the task plan is updated. In the case of removing a bundled offering, customization to the task plan is overwritten; In the case of adding a bundled offering, customization to the task plan isn't overwritten.

To define a task plan, do one of the following:

  • Define a task and approval plan in the offering record. For more information, see Task plans.
    You can also copy the task plan from a fulfillment plan to the offering record and then edit the plan. To do this, select a fulfillment plan from the Fulfillment Plan drop-down list, and then click Copy task plan from fulfillment plan.
    Note: If there are user options used in the task plan of the fulfillment plan but the user options are only available in the fulfillment plan, the task plan might not work in the offering after you copy the task plan from the fulfillment plan to the offering.

  • If you select a fulfillment plan to populate the user options (earlier), the fulfillment plan's task plan populates the offering's task plan.

    For a support offering, you can select a fulfillment plan of type Support Request.
    For a case offering, you can select a fulfillment plan of type Case Request.

    For a service offering, you can select a fulfillment plan of type Service Request or Cloud Service Request.

    Note: The fulfillment plan for Cloud Service Request type doesn't contain user options.

    To edit the task plan, click Edit fulfillment plan, and edit the task plan in the fulfillment plan itself.

    Keep in mind that when you update a fulfillment plan it affects all offerings that consume this fulfillment plan.

    For more details about fulfillment plans, see How to create or edit a fulfillment plan.
     

    To clear the selection, click the button in the Fulfillment Plan field.

For aggregated offerings, note the following:

  • When you create an aggregated offering, the system adds a default fulfillment task plan to the aggregated offering to support the required actions. This release supports Create Subscription, Modify Subscription, Cancel Subscription, and Transfer Subscription in the out-of-the-box task plan for fulfillment.
  • The sub task plan of Modify Subscription will take effect when the subscription action type is "Update."

Approvals for user operations in cloud offerings

When you build a task/approval plan, you can design the approval workflow for the user operations.

Note that the fix for issue OCTCR19M1918118 requires additional customer actions. If you have defined approvals on user operations before this fix, you must log in as catalog admin and manually click Retrieve user operations to refresh the user operation list and redefine the approvals based on the newly retrieved user operation names.

There are two ways to add variations of approvers based on user operation names:

  1. You can add branches to the approval plan based on the user operation names.

    1. In the Task Plan tab, click Retrieve user operations to get the user operation list from DND service design.
      Note: As the user operation list might be changed in DND from time to time, be sure to get the latest user operation list before you create an approval plan.
    2. Copy the user operation name from the User operations list, which is the value shown in the brackets. 
      In the following example, the name of the first user operation is "074951c7-7b5d-c14b-d2ac-dc78ee9c619d-dacd195a-bdc4-46ab-8c85-7189025eb8d5".
    3. Add a Decision in the approval plan, then select Advanced. In the In case of field, input the expression as ${entity.ServiceInstanceUserOperationName}. In the output values field, enter the user operation name copied in the above step.

  2. You can add conditions in the Approval Task based on the user operation name.

    1. In the Task Plan tab, click Retrieve user operations to get the user operation list from DND service design.
      Note: As the user operation list might be changed in DND from time to time, be sure to get the latest user operation list before you create an approval plan.
    2. Copy the user operation name from the User operations list, which is the value shown in the brackets. 
      In the following example, the name of the first user operation is "074951c7-7b5d-c14b-d2ac-dc78ee9c619d-dacd195a-bdc4-46ab-8c85-7189025eb8d5".
    3. Add an approval task directly in the approval plan. In the following example where different Approvers can be assigned, you can define the related user operation name in the Condition value.
      For example: ${entity.ServiceInstanceUserOperationName=='074951c7-7b5d-c14b-d2ac-dc78ee9c619d-dacd195a-bdc4-46ab-8c85-7189025eb8d5'}.

Default values tab

Simple and Expression Language modes

For the fields in the Default values tab, the following are available:

  • Simple Mode. Enter the default value in the text box, or for a list, select a value from the drop-down list, or select or deselect an option field.
  • Expression Language Mode. Enter an Expression Language phrase that returns the default value.

Click the Expression Language button to toggle between these options. The field is in Expression Language mode when you select the button (blue). When it's not selected (white), the field is in Simple mode. For a full list of Expression Language functions, see Expression Language functions and syntax.

In this tab, you can define default values for the Request and User options fields. These values appear in the requests where you consume the offerings. You can edit these values.

This tab includes the Skip end user acceptance option. If selected, the system adjusts the workflow for requests based on the offering to bypass the Validation Metaphase. Out of the box, if selected, this option applies to Service and Support Requests. It doesn't apply to HR Support Requests.

There may be certain circumstances where you consider validation isn't required. For example, where the system provides a standard solution. In such cases, you can remove the need for end user acceptance by enabling Skip end user acceptance.

Note: For an offering (not the aggregated offering), the system won't save the expanding or collapsing status of the user option group defined in the Default values tab. By default in Service Portal, all option groups are in collapsed state.

Limitation

M:M associations are not supported to be set as default values of a request, so you can't add an M:M Grid to the Default values tab of an offering.
